question.title: Where should DTO to Entity/ID translation and lookup occur in a multi-layered Spring application?
question.body:
I'm building a RESTful API using Spring Boot with a standard layered architecture: Controller (Resource) -> Facade -> Service -> Repository.

I have an incoming Data Transfer Object (ProductRequestDto) which uses codes/natural keys for some relationships (like imageCodes and countryCode). My internal persistence Entity (Product) uses Foreign Key IDs for these same relationships (imageIds and countryId).

Before the Product entity is passed to the ProductService for persistence, I need to:

  1. Translate/Lookup the natural keys (e.g., countryCode) into foreign key IDs (e.g., countryId). This lookup will likely involve a separate repository/service call (e.g., countryRepository.findByCode(countryCode)).

  2. Map the remaining properties from the ProductRequestDto to the Product entity.

In which layer/component should this lookup and translation logic reside?

Should it be in the Mapper, the Facade, or the Service layer?

If I had a validation service that needed to check and alert the user that he had conflicting or too many images, where would that belong?

Thank you!


@Getter
@Setter
public class ProductRequestDto {
    private Long id;
    private String code;
    private String name;
    private String description;
    private BigDecimal price;
    private Set<Long> imageCodes; //Here as codes
        private String countryCode; //Here as code
    private Boolean active;
    private Instant createdAt;
    private Instant updatedAt;
}


@Getter
@Setter
public class Product {
    private Long id;
    private String code;
    private String name;
    private String description;
    private BigDecimal price;
    private Set<Long> imageIds; //Here as image ids (fk)
        private Long countryId;  //Here as country Id (fk)
    private Boolean active;
    private Instant createdAt;
    private Instant updatedAt;
}


@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api")
public class ProductResource {

    private final ProductFacade productFacade;

    @Autowired
    public ProductResource(ProductFacade productFacade) {
        this.productFacade = productFacade;
    }

    @PostMapping("/v1/products")
    public ProductResponseDto createProduct(@RequestBody CreateProductDto createProductDto){
        return productFacade.createProduct(createProductDto);
    }

}


@Component
public class ProductFacade {

    private final ProductService productService;
    private final ProductMapper productMapper;

    @Autowired
    public ProductFacade(ProductService productService, ProductMapper productMapper) {
        this.productService = productService;
        this.productMapper = productMapper;
    }

    public ProductResponseDto createProduct(ProductRequestDto dto) {
        Product product = productMapper.toProduct(dto);
        Product createdProduct = productService.createProduct(product);
        return productMapper.toProductDto(createdProduct);
    }

}



@Component
public class ProductService {

    private final ProductRepository productRepository;

    @Autowired
    public ProductService(ProductRepository productRepository) {
        this.productRepository = productRepository;
    }

    public Product createProduct(Product product) {

        return productRepository.createProduct(product);
    }

}

answers.body:
The facade is the right place for code-to-ID resolution. It's designed for orchestration between external representations and internal domain models. Keep your mapper as a pure transformation function without repository dependencies.

@Component
public class ProductFacade {

    private final ProductService productService;
    private final ProductMapper productMapper;
    private final CountryLookupService countryLookupService;
    private final ImageLookupService imageLookupService;

    public ProductResponseDto createProduct(ProductRequestDto dto) {
        // 1. Resolve codes to IDs
        Long countryId = countryLookupService.resolveCountryId(dto.getCountryCode());
        Set<Long> imageIds = imageLookupService.resolveImageIds(dto.getImageCodes());

        // 2. Map DTO to entity with resolved IDs
        Product product = productMapper.toProduct(dto, countryId, imageIds);

        // 3. Delegate to service
        Product created = productService.createProduct(product);
        return productMapper.toProductDto(created);
    }
}

and a mappr

@Component
public class ProductMapper {

    public Product toProduct(ProductRequestDto dto, Long countryId, Set<Long> imageIds) {
        Product product = new Product();
        product.setCode(dto.getCode());
        product.setName(dto.getName());
        product.setDescription(dto.getDescription());
        product.setPrice(dto.getPrice());
        product.setCountryId(countryId);
        product.setImageIds(imageIds);
        product.setActive(dto.getActive());
        return product;
    }
}

and the validation depends on the type.

If you have Format/constraint validation for example:

@PostMapping("/v1/products")
public ProductResponseDto createProduct(@RequestBody @Valid ProductRequestDto dto) {
    return productFacade.createProduct(dto);
}

Then in controller. If it is a business validation (conflicting images, too many images), then service layer.

@Component
public class ProductService {

    private final ProductRepository productRepository;
    private final ProductValidationService validationService;

    public Product createProduct(Product product) {
        validationService.validateImages(product.getImageIds());
        return productRepository.createProduct(product);
    }
}

@Component
public class ProductValidationService {

    public void validateImages(Set<Long> imageIds) {
        if (imageIds.size() > 10) {
            throw new BusinessValidationException("Maximum 10 images allowed");
        }
       
    }
}

79846777.body: if the aggregate needs that data to function correctly, hydrate in the service. If you're just assembling a view for the client, hydrate in the facade.
Awesome, one last question if you don't mind, since Product is an aggregate, do you know where hydration should be (Facade vs Service)?

@SnarkyWombat Good question. For most applications, just use the existing CountryService directly. A separate LookupService makes sense only when for exmple: You need caching specifically for lookups (countries rarely change, so an in-memory cache is sensible), the lookup logic becomes complex, you want to batch multiple lookups efficiently or you're in a large codebase where teams own different services. For a typical CRUD service with a findByCode method, introducing an extra layer just adds indirection without benefit.

This is an excellent explanation. Thank you :)  As a quick aside, say you have this service:  CountryLookupService countryLookupService  But you also have a service with CRUD operations for country (e.g. Country Service).  Would you recommend using the country service or having a separate country lookup service like you do to separate concerns?
